title: Standard Form
text: Write the equation in standard form. $$\frac{x^2}{a^2}-\frac{y^2}{b^2}=1$$.

title: Horizontal or Vertical
text: Determine whether the transverse axis is horizontal or vertical.

title: Horizontal or Vertical
text: If the $$x^2$$ is positive, then the transverse axis is horizontal, and if the $$y^2$$ term is positive, then the transverse axis is vertical.

title: Horizontal or Vertical
text: In our case, the transverse axis is horizontal since $$x^2$$ is positive.

title: Finding the Center
text: Since the equation is in the form of $$\frac{{\left(x-h\right)}^2}{a^2}-\frac{{\left(y-k\right)}^2}{b^2}=1$$, we can find our center, which is shown from h and k.

title: Finding the Center
text: To find the center, we look for h and k, which in this case is $$h=2$$ and $$k=3$$, so our center is located at (2,3).

title: Vertices
text: To find the vertices, we find the square root of $$a^2$$ and the square root of $$b^2$$.

title: Vertices
text: In our case, a is $$\pm 2$$, and b is $$\pm 4$$.

title: Asymptotes
text: Now, we sketch a rectangle around our center using our found a and b.

title: Asymptotes
text: We then sketch two diagonal lines from the corners of the rectanges and through the center, which will outline our asymptotes.

title: Asymptotes
text: We can then draw the hyperbola with the rectangle and lines as our guides.
